analytic.title: Covering based rough set approximations

biblStruct.note: Received 11 November 2009 Received in revised form 21 January 2012 Accepted 29 February 2012

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Approximation operator Closure system Covering Neighborhood Rough set

div.p: We propose a framework for the study of covering based rough set approximations. Three equivalent formulations of the classical rough sets are examined by using equivalence relations, partitions, and r-algebras, respectively. They suggest the element based, the granule based and the subsystem based definitions of approximation operators. Covering based rough sets are systematically investigated by generalizing these formulations and definitions. A covering of universe of objects is used to generate different neighborhood operators, neighborhood systems, coverings, and subsystems of the power set of the universe. They are in turn used to define different types of generalized approximation operators. Within the proposed framework, we review and discuss covering based approximation operators according to the element, granule, and subsystem based definitions.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: A fundamental assumption of the theory of rough sets is that relationship, more precisely indiscernibility, of objects is defined by an equivalence relation, or equivalently a partition of the universe [36,37]. Ever since the introduction of rough sets in the early 1980s, many attempts have been made to remove this assumption. By the fact that a covering is a generalization of a partition, it is natural to investigate covering based generalizations of rough sets.

A review of existing studies shows a great diversity of research on covering based rough sets (see Section 2). There is a recent surge of interest on this topic; new approximation operators are constantly being proposed and studied. On the other hand, there is still a lack of a common framework within which existing results can be classified and summarized systematically and coherently. The main objective of this paper is to serve such a purpose. We propose a general framework for the study of covering based rough sets and summarize and extend existing results within the framework.

Our framework is inspired by an insightful comment by Feynman [18] on the character of physical law. Feynman points out the importance of deriving different, but mathematically equivalent, formulations of the same physical law. Although different formulations are mathematically equivalent, they are psychologically unequivalent. Different possible formulations give distinctive clues when one guesses new laws in a wider situation. When this argument is applied to the study of covering based rough sets, we must consider different but equivalent formulations of the Pawlak approximation operators and examine their possible generalizations. In fact, our previous studies on generalized rough sets explored the important roles of multiple formulations [59][60][61][62][63]65,69], which serves as a basis of this paper. As pointed by one reviewer of this article, the same argument can be applied to study reducts in rough set theory through a ''comparison of equivalent ways of formulating decision reducts in consistent decision tables, which are not equivalent any longer in case of inconsistent tables or in case of approximate reduction criteria. '' In the Pawlak rough set model, an equivalence relation offers two additional equivalent structures. One is the partition induced by the equivalence relation, and the other is the atomic Boolean algebra with the partition as its set of atoms.

The latter is also an r-algebra with each element being the union of a family of equivalence classes from the partition. Consequently, we can obtain three equivalent formulations of rough sets, namely, the equivalence relation based formulation, the partition based formulation, and the r-algebra based formulation. They immediately offer hints to generalizing Pawlak rough sets in three directions [65]. One may consider an arbitrary binary relation in generalizing the equivalence relation, a covering in generalizing the partition, and a subsystem in generalizing the r-algebra. With each formulation, one may also examine various definitions of approximation operators. In this paper, we choose the element based definition for relation based formulation, the granule based definition for the partition based formulation, and the subsystem based definition for r-algebra based formulation [65]. The same argument can be easily applied when other definitions are used.

Unlike the case of an equivalence relation, given a covering of the universe, one can define several binary relations, or equivalently 1-neighborhood operators [61,66], new coverings, and subsystems. Consequently, we can derive many different approximation operators based on the three definitions. They include many existing approximation operators and new ones.

The main ideas of the proposed framework are summarized in Fig. 1, where , indicates a one-to-one two-way construction process, ) indicates a one way construction process, and G ? indicates a connection of a notion to its generalization. It needs to be pointed out that the discussion of this paper is restricted to a finite universe; some results may not necessarily hold for an infinite universe.

According to the framework given by Fig. 1, the rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 reviews the main results from existing studies, which motivates the current research. Section 3 proposes a unified framework by considering three different, but equivalent, formulations of rough sets and three different, but equivalent, definitions of approximation operators. They lead to three directions in generalizing approximation operators. Section 4 investigates various structures induced by a covering of a finite universe. Section 5 defines twenty pairs of approximation operators by using these structures and classifies and characterizes approximation operators introduced in other studies.

div.head: A brief review of studies on covering based rough sets
div.p: The results from the main studies on covering based rough sets are summarized in this section to motivate the current research. More details can be found in Table 2 and discussions in Section 5.

In 1983, _ Zakowski [71] first proposed the notion of covering based rough set approximations. A pair of lower and upper approximation operators are defined by a straightforward generalization of the Pawlak definition. However, unlike the Pawlak approximation operators, the generalized approximation operators are no longer dual to each other with respect to set complement [38,61]. By modifying _ Zakowski's definition, Pomykała [38] studied two pairs of dual approximation operators. The lower approximation operator in one pair is the same as _ Zakowski lower approximation operator, and the upper approximation operator in the other pair is the same as _ Zakowski upper approximation operator. By using other mathematical structures induced by a covering, Pomykała [39] suggested and examined additional pairs of dual approximation operators. Furthermore, he considered coverings produced by tolerance relations (i.e., reflexive and symmetric relations) in an incomplete information table. In particular, each subset in the covering is called an elementary set induced by the tolerance relation, which is also called a maximal tolerance block or a maximal consistent block by some authors [3,21].

Yao [61,65] investigated dual approximation operators by using coverings produced by the predecessor and/or successor neighborhoods of serial or inverse serial binary relations. The two pairs of dual approximation operators introduced by Pomykała [38,39] were examined and the conditions for their equivalence to those obtained from a binary relation were given. Couso and Dubois [12] referred to the two pairs as the loose pair and the tight pair, respectively. They presented an interesting investigation of the two pairs of approximation operators within the context of incomplete information. The two pairs of operators were shown to be related to the family of approximation operators produced by all partitions consistent with a covering induced by an ill-known attribute function in an incomplete information table. The result provides a theoretical justification supporting the adoption of the two pairs of operators. Instead of using the duality, Wybraniec-Skardowska [55] studied pairs of approximation operators linked together by a different type of relations. Given an upper approximation operator, the corresponding lower approximation operator is defined based on the upper approximations of singleton subsets. Several such pairs of approximation operators were studied based on a covering and a tolerance relation defined by a covering, including some of these used by _ Zakowski [71] and Pomykała [38].

Bryniarski [7] investigated a different pair of approximation operators. The lower approximation operator is the same as _ Zakowski lower approximation operator, but the upper approximation operator is different. The two operators are linked together by the approximation condition satisfied by a covering, namely, for every pair of subsets in a covering, if one is a subset of the other, there must exist a set such that these two subsets are the lower and upper approximations of the set. In other words, Bryniarski considered a special type of coverings. Related to Bryniarski's study, Bonikowski et al. [6] introduced the notion of the minimal description of an object (i.e., the set of all minimal subsets containing the object in a covering) induced by a covering and examined a new pair of approximation operators. The lower approximation operator is again the same as _ Zakowski lower approximation operator, but the upper approximation operator is different. Based on these earlier studies, starting in 2001, there is a surge of research interest in covering based rough sets. The investigations can be divided into two groups. One group focused on new dual pairs of approximation operators, in addition to the two pairs studied by Pomykała [38,39] and Yao [61,65]. The other group focused on non-dual approximation operators. Studies on non-dual approximation operators can be further divided into two subgroups. One of them investigated _ Zakowski approximation operators with respect to specific types of coverings; the other, with major contributions from Zhu and his associates [77,78,81,84,86,87], accepted only _ Zakowski lower approximation and proposed new upper approximations. The upper approximations were introduced in a way suggested by Bryniarski [7] and Bonikowski et al. [6]; they normally fall within the Bryniarski and _ Zakowski upper approximations. S ´le ˛zak and Wasilewski [44,52] studied the pair of _ Zakowski approximation operators based on a covering induced by a tolerance relation. In most cases, approximation operators studied in the latter group are not dual operators.

By using the minimum neighborhood of an object (i.e., the intersection of subsets in the minimal description of the object), Wang et al. [47] introduced a pair of dual approximation operators. The same pair of approximation operators was also used and examined by Xu and Wang [57] and Xu and Zhang [56]. Liu and Sai [31] gave an axiomatic system for this pair of approximation operators. Li [24] introduced two pairs of approximation operators in a similar way, but used two different neighborhoods of an object. Qin et al. [40] studied five pairs of dual approximation operators based on a covering and the minimum neighborhood induced by a covering. The connections between the five pairs were investigated. In fact, their first two pairs are the same as the ones introduced by Pomykała [38,39], Yao [61,65], and Wang et al. [47].

Mordeson [33] examined the pair of _ Zakowski approximation operators by considering special types of coverings, namely, semi-reduced and reduced coverings with respect to set union. Similarly, Chen et al. [8] used the _ Zakowski approximation operators by considering a covering induced by the original covering and a covering induced by a family of coverings.

In comparison, the majority of studies on non-dual approximation operators introduced new upper approximation operators. Zhu and his associates [77][78][79][80][81][82][83][84][85][86][87] systematically studied five types of approximation operators. They consist of new approximation operators and those existing ones studied by _ Zakowski [71], Pomykała [38,39], Yao [61], Wang et al. [47], Xu and Wang [57], and others. While the lower approximation operator is the _ Zakowski lower approximation operator, the upper approximation operators are different. Zhu and associates investigated properties of these operators and their relationships; they also provided sets of axioms for characterizing these operators. Their studies represent a step towards a general framework for the study of various approximation operators. More examples of studies on non-dual approximation operators are given below. Tsang et al. [46] defined an upper approximation operator by the union of all subsets in the minimal description of each object in the set to be approximated. Chen et al. [9] defined two pairs approximation operators based on the difference between the set and a neighborhood of the set induced by a covering. Wu et al. [53] introduced another upper approximation operator and studied its relationship to operators proposed by Zhu. Zhang et al. [73] established independent axiomatic systems to characterize three pairs of covering based approximation operators.

Zhu and Wang [82,83] introduced the concept of a reduct of a covering, which provides another way to construct a reduced covering from the original covering. This topic was further studied by some authors [8,22]. There are several additional research topics related to covering based rough sets, including, for example, topological structures induced by approximation operators [23,33,79] and approximation operators based on fuzzy coverings [13,16,24,25].

Although many different covering based approximation operators have been proposed and studied extensively, there does not exist a framework to put all these studies together. Moreover, the semantics of different approximation operators are not entirely clear. This is particular true for non-dual approximation operators. There is no convincing argument to support that one lower approximation is associated with many upper approximations. It is expected that new approximation operators will be proposed by researchers in the near future in much an ad hoc manner. All of these call for a general framework and a more systematic formulation of covering based rough sets.

Since the submission of the first version of this paper in November 2009, we have in fact witnessed another wave of studies on covering based rough sets. For completeness, we briefly review studies since then based on a list of sample, nonexhausive publications.

Samanta and Chakraborty [41] provided a systematic study and survey of about ten pairs of approximation operators, their properties, and their implication lattices. Wang et al. [48][49][50] discussed poset approaches to covering based rough sets, introduced the notion of covering numbers for a quantitative study, and investigated matroidal structures of covering based rough sets.

Li et al. [28] defined a binary relation based on the relative number of common subsets in a covering for pairs of elements and introduced a pair of approximations operators based on the induced binary relation. Abo-Tabl [1] examined two types of rough set approximation based on a similarity relation and studied their connections to covering based rough set approximations. Zhu [75] showed that one can construct upper approximations without explicitly using neighborhoods. Liu and Miao [30] introduced covering based rough sets using multi-granulations. Lin and Li [29] studied covering based rough sets based on pessimistic multi-granulations. Zheng and Dai [74] considered a variable precision model of covering based rough sets. Zhang and Luo [72] gave a minimal set of axioms for covering based approximations. Yun et al. [70] presented another axiomatic study on covering based rough sets.

Yang and Li [58] and Li and Wu [26] studied attribute reduction in covering based rough sets, and Feng et al. [17] studied reduction of fuzzy covering systems. Du et al. [15] presented algorithms for rule discovery based on coverings defined by neighborhoods of numerical attributes values.

Shi and Gong [42], and Zhu and Wen [76] examined uncertainty measures in covering based rough sets. Bianucci et al. [4,5] investigated systematically entropy and co-entropy of a covering. Ge et al. [19] studied granularity-wise separation in covering approximation spaces. Ciucci [10] studied temporal dynamics in covering based on rough sets. Diker and Ug ˘ur [14] examined the connections between textures and covering based rough sets. Li and Liu [27] investigated covering based rough sets using matroid theory.

Based on a review of these recent studies, our observations and conclusions made in 2009 are still applicable today. In fact, the need for a unified framework for studying covering based rough sets is even more urgent.

div.head: A framework for formulating rough set approximations
div.p: We present a general framework for formulating rough set approximations in two steps. In the first step, we examine three mathematically equivalent definitions of Pawlak rough set approximations; in the second step, we study different directions of generalizations according to each of the three definitions.

div.head: Three definitions of Pawlak rough set approximations
div.p: Suppose U is a finite and non-empty set called the universe. Let E # U Â U be an equivalence relation on U. The pair apr = (U, E) is called an approximation space [36,37]. A few definitions of rough set approximations can be derived based on different representations of an equivalence relation.
An equivalence relation E can be conveniently represented by a mapping from U to P(U), where P(U) is the power set of U. More specifically, the mapping [Á] E is given by:
div.formula: ½x E ¼ fyjy 2 U; xEyg:ð1Þ
div.p: The subset [x] E is the equivalence class containing x. The family of all equivalence classes is commonly known as the quotient set and is denoted by
div.formula: U/E = {[x] E jx 2 U}.
div.p: It defines a partition of the universe, namely, a family of pairwise disjoint non-empty subsets whose union is the universe. A new family of subsets, denoted by r(U/E), can be obtained from U/E by adding the empty set ; and making it closed under set union, which is a subsystem of P(U), that is, r(U/E) # P(U). In fact, it is an r-algebra of subsets of U and a sub-Boolean algebra of the Boolean algebra (P(U), $, \, [), where $, \, and [ represent set complement, intersection and union, respectively. Furthermore, r(U/E) defines uniquely a topological space (U, r(U/E)), in which r(U/E) is the family of all open and closed sets [36].

Under the equivalence relation, we have a coarsened view of the universe. Each equivalence class is considered as a whole granule instead of many individuals [64]. They are considered as the elementary definable, observable, or measurable subsets of the universe [37,67]. The definability of sets can be formally expressed in terms of a logic language in an information table. More precisely, a set is definable if it can be characterized by a logic formula [67]. By the construction of r(U/E), all subsets in r(U/E) are definable. To a large extent, the standard rough set theory deals with the approximation of any subset of U in terms of definable subsets in r(U/E). From the different representations of an equivalence relation, one can obtain three definitions of Pawlak rough set approximations [65].

Definition 1. In an approximation space apr = (U, E) with E being an equivalence relation on U, the Pawlak rough set approximations are defined by the following three equivalent definitions: Element based definition:
div.formula: aprðAÞ ¼ fxjx 2 U; ½x E # Ag ¼ fxjx 2 U; 8y 2 U½xEy ) y 2 Ag; aprðAÞ ¼ fxjx 2 U; ½x E \ A -;g ¼ fxjx 2 U; 9y 2 U½xEy; y 2 Ag;ð2Þ
div.p: Granule based definition:
div.formula: aprðAÞ ¼ [ f½x E j½x E 2 U=E; ½x E # Ag ¼ [ fXjX 2 U=E; X # Ag; aprðAÞ ¼ [ f½x E j½x E 2 U=E; ½x E \ A -;g ¼ [ fXjX 2 U=E; X \ A -;g;ð3Þ
div.p: Subsystem based definition:
div.formula: aprðAÞ ¼ [ fXjX 2 rðU=EÞ; X # Ag; aprðAÞ ¼ \ fXjX 2 rðU=EÞ; A # Xg:ð4Þ
div.p: The three equivalent definitions offer different interpretations of rough set approximations. According to the element based definition, an element x is in the lower approximation apr(A) of a set A if all its equivalent elements are in A; the element is in the upper approximation aprðAÞ if at least one of its equivalent elements is in A. According to the granule based definition, apr(A) is the union of equivalence classes that are subsets of A, aprðAÞ is the union of equivalence classes that have a non-empty intersection with A. According to the subsystem based definition, apr(A) is the largest definable set in the subsystem r(U/E) that is contained in A, aprðAÞ is the smallest definable subset in r(U/E) that contains the set A.

Grzymala-Busse [20] refers to the element based and granule based definitions as the singleton based approximations and the subset based approximations, respectively. In general, one may use other equivalent definitions. For example, one may use a concept based definition [20]:
div.formula: aprðAÞ ¼ [ f½x E jx 2 A; ½x E # Ag aprðAÞ ¼ [ f½x E jx 2 A; ½x E \ A -;g ¼ [ f½x E jx 2 Ag:ð5Þ
div.p: It may be considered as a variant of the granule based definition. Instead of using the entire universe, the concept based definition restricts x to the set A. Many covering based approximation operators in fact rely on the concept based definition [6,7].

The three equivalent definitions are the most commonly used ones in rough set literature [37,59,[61][62][63][64]68]. They represent three research directions, and hence are sufficient for our development of a general framework. The argument presented in the paper can be easily applied to other definitions of rough set approximations.

The pair of rough set approximations may be viewed as a pair of dual unary operations with respect to set complement, namely, apr; apr : PðUÞ ! PðUÞ. Thus, we have an algebra ðPðUÞ; $; apr; apr; \; [Þ, which may be viewed as a set algebra with added operators [59,60]. In this paper, we also call rough set approximations shortly as approximation operators.

div.head: Generalized approximation operators
div.p: The Pawlak approximation operators satisfy many properties [36,37]. When generalizing Pawlak approximations, one task is to specify a subset of these properties that new approximation operators are required to preserve. Another task is to search for possible generalizations of the various notions used in the three definitions. Furthermore, one must make sure that the generalized approximation operators satisfy the required properties.
In this paper, we consider the following two properties suggested by Pomykała [39]: for all A # U, ðiÞ aprðAÞ ¼ $ aprð$ AÞ; aprðAÞ ¼ $ aprð$ AÞ; ðiiaÞ aprðAÞ # aprðAÞ;
ðiibÞ aprðAÞ # A # aprðAÞ:

Properties in (i) state that apr and apr are a pair of dual operators with respect to set complement. By imposing (i), we restrict our discussion to dual approximation operations in the proposed framework. For a review of existing studies in Section 5, we also include non-dual operators. Property (iia) can be viewed as a weaker version of (iib). Property (iia) requires that the lower approximation is a subset of the upper approximation. It makes the interpretation of the basic characteristics of approximations to be consistent with the common understanding of the phrases of ''lower'' and ''upper'' approximations. Property (iib) further requires that A lies within its lower and upper approximations. The property A # aprðAÞ is commonly known as the extensive property. The requirement for duality has been emphasized by many authors [38][39][40]61,65]. On the other hand, some authors also studied pairs of operations linked in other ways. Wybraniec-Skardowska [55] suggested that an upper approximation operator satisfies the condition: ðiiiÞ aprðAÞ ¼ S x2A aprðfxgÞ:
The corresponding lower approximation operator is defined by
div.formula: aprðAÞ ¼ fxjx 2 U; ; -aprðfxgÞ # Ag:ð6Þ
div.p: This definition is closely related to the notion of an upper approximation distribution proposed by Yao [63]. In general, an upper approximation distribution is a mapping h: U ? P(U) satisfying the condition S x2U h(x) = U. In terms of an upper approximation distribution, Wybraniec-Skardowska approximation operators can be expressed as:
div.formula: aprðAÞ ¼ fxjx 2 U; ; -hðxÞ # Ag aprðAÞ ¼ S x2A hðxÞ:ð7Þ
div.p: They are not necessarily dual operators. A pair of dual operators can be defined by:
div.formula: aprðAÞ ¼ T xRA ð$ hðxÞÞ; aprðAÞ ¼ S x2A hðxÞ:ð8Þ
div.p: If an upper approximation distribution h satisfies the condition x 2 h(x), both Wybraniec-Skardowska approximation operators and the pair of dual approximation operators satisfy (iib). Given an upper approximation operator apr satisfying the condition, aprðA [ BÞ ¼ aprðAÞ [ aprðBÞ, for all A, B # U, h can be defined by hðxÞ ¼ aprðfxgÞ.

Based on a covering of the universe, Bryniarski [7] introduced a pair of approximation operators by using _ Zakowski lower approximation operator and a new upper approximation operator. They are not a pair of dual approximation operators. However, they linked together by the so-called approximation condition. That is, for every pair of subsets in a covering, if one is a subset of the other, there must exist a set such that these two subsets are the lower and upper approximation of the set.

In contrast, many studies on non-dual approximation operators did not address fully the issue about the linkage or relationship between a particular pair of operators. Without establishing such a connection, one has no reason to investigate them jointly as a pair, rather than individually. For this reason, we insist on the duality of a pair of approximation operators.

div.head: Element based approximation operators
div.p: In the element based definition, the equivalence class [x] E may be viewed as an neighborhood of x, consisting of objects equivalent to x. In general, one may consider any neighborhood of x, consisting of objects related to x. In order to make it to be a well-defined definition, we must use exactly one neighborhood for each object x 2 U. This gives a generalization of element based definition.
The following theorem [61] shows that the generalized approximation operators have the desired properties (i) and (ii).

Theorem 1. The approximation operators apr n and apr n are a pair of dual operators, that is, they satisfy property (i). Furthermore, apr n and apr n satisfy property (iia) if and only if n is a serial neighborhood operator. They satisfy property (iib) if and only if n is a reflexive neighborhood operator.
A neighborhood operator can be defined by using a binary relation [34,35,45,51,54,61,69]. Suppose R # U Â U is a binary relation. A successor neighborhood operator R S : U ? P(U) can be defined as:
div.formula: R S ðxÞ ¼ fyjy 2 U; xRyg:ð10Þ
div.p: Conversely, a binary relation can be reconstructed from its successful neighborhood as:
div.formula: xRy () y 2 R S ðxÞ:ð11Þ
div.p: That is, generalized approximations by a neighborhood operator can be equivalently formulated by using a binary relation. This formulation connects generalized approximation operators with the necessity and possibility operators in modal logic [69]. Many authors studied generalized approximation operators defined by neighborhood operators induced by a binary relation or a family of binary relations [2,54,59,61,63,69,80].

div.head: Granule based approximation operators
div.p: The granule based definition uses equivalence granules in the partition U/E. A generalized mathematical structure of a partition is a covering of a universe. Thus, the granule based definition can be generalized by using a covering. Definition 4. Let U be a universe and C be a family of non-empty subsets of U. If S C ¼ U; C is called a covering of U. _ Zakowski [71] suggested a straightforward definition of approximation operators based on a covering, in which the equivalence class is replaced by a set in a covering. However, the approximation operators thus defined are not a pair of dual approximation operators [38,61]. To overcome this problem, as suggested by Pomykała [38,39] and Yao [61,65], one can generalize one of them and define the other by duality. This leads to two pairs of dual approximation operators.
Definition 5 (Granule based definition). For a covering C of U, two pairs of approximation operators ðaprC 0 ; apr 0 C Þ and ðaprC 00 ; apr 00 C Þ are defined as:
div.formula: apr 0 C ðAÞ ¼ [ fKjK 2 C; K # Ag ¼ fxjx 2 U; 9K 2 C½x 2 K; K # Ag; apr 0 C ðAÞ ¼ $ apr 0 C ð$ AÞ ¼ fxjx 2 U; 8K 2 C½x 2 K ) K \ A -;g;ð12Þ
apr 00 C ðAÞ ¼ $ apr 00 C ð$ AÞ ¼ fxjx 2 U; 8K 2 C½x 2 K ) K # Ag; apr 00 C ðAÞ ¼ [ fKjK 2 C; K \ A -;g ¼ fxjx 2 U; 9K 2 C½x 2 K; K \ A -;g:ð13Þ
div.p: The two pairs of operators have the desired properties (i) and (iib) as shown by the following theorem [61].
Theorem 2. Let C be a covering of universe U. The two pairs of approximation operators ðaprC 0 ; apr 0 C Þand ðaprC 00 ; apr 00 C Þ satisfy properties (i) and (iib).
For the upper approximation operator apr 00 C , one may expressed it in terms of the concept based definition as follows [38]:
div.formula: apr 00 C ðAÞ ¼ [ x2A fKjx 2 K; K 2 Cg:ð14Þ
div.p: It provides another definition that may be used when generalizing approximation operators. The two pairs of approximation operators are connected by the following relationship [12,38,39]: for all A # U, apr 00 C ðAÞ # apr 0 C ðAÞ # X # apr 0 C ðAÞ # apr 00 C ðAÞ: ð15Þ

Thus, the first pair may be viewed as a tight pair [12] or strong approximations [38] and the second pair as a loose pair [12] or weak approximations [38]. Couso and Dubois [12] provided an interesting interpretation of these two pairs of approximation operators in the context of incomplete information. They may be related to the family of lower and upper approximations defined by all partitions consistent with a covering. For this reason, we focus mainly on these two pairs.

div.head: Subsystem based approximation operators
div.p: To generalize the subsystem based definition, for the lower approximation we must use a subsystem that is closed under union, and for the upper approximation we must use a subsystem that is closed under intersection [62,68]. To ensure the duality of approximation operators, the two subsystems must be dual systems with respect to set complement. Such mathematical structures are related to closure systems [11]. Definition 6. A family of subsets of universe U is called a closure system over U if it contains U and is closed under set intersection.
Given a closure system S, one can construct its dual system S as follows:
div.formula: S ¼ f$XjX 2 Sg:ð16Þ
div.p: The system S contains ; and is closed under set union. Generalized approximation operators with respect to subsystem based definition are defined by using a pair of a closure system and its dual system [62,68].

Definition 7 (Subsystem based definition). Suppose S ¼ ðS; SÞ is a pair of subsystems of P(U), S is a closure system and S is the dual system of S. A pair of lower and upper approximation operators ðapr S ; apr S Þ with respect to S is defined as:
div.formula: apr S ðAÞ ¼ [ fXjX 2 S; X # Ag; apr S ðAÞ ¼ \ fXjX 2 S; X Ag:ð17Þ
div.p: The lower and upper approximation operators defined by a pair of subsystems have the desired properties (i) and (iib) as shown by the following theorem [62,68]. Theorem 3. Suppose S ¼ ðS; SÞ is a pair of dual subsystems with S being a closure system. The pair of approximation operators apr S and apr S satisfies (i) and (iib).

As a special case, the two systems S and S may be the same, namely, S ¼ S, which is closed under set complement, union and intersection. That is, it is a Boolean algebra. This special case corresponds to the Pawlak model. The subsystem based definition provides a way to approximate any set in P(U) by a pair of sets in S and S, respectively. By observing the fact that P(U) is a poset, a lattice and at the same time a Boolean algebra, one can easily apply the subsystem based formulation by using these mathematical structures [62,65,68].

div.head: Structures induced by a covering
div.p: Let C denote the set of all coverings of U. Given a covering C 2 C, there are two possible ways to formulation covering based approximation operators. One is to use directly the covering C to replace the partition U/E in the granule based definition as shown in the last section. The other is to define first neighborhood operators, new coverings, and subsystems from C, and then use the three definitions. This section investigates the structures needed in the latter approach.

div.head: Neighborhood system induced by a covering
div.p: In his book on general topology, Sierpin ´ski [43] introduces the notion of a Fréchet (V) Space, that is, a set U of elements in which each element x 2 U is associated with one or more subsets of U called neighborhoods of x, but these neighborhoods need not satisfy any additional conditions. A Fréchet (V) Space, or simply a (V) Space, is defined by its system of neighborhoods. There is a close connection between a covering and neighborhood systems of objects in the universe. Definition 8. A Fréchet (V) Space is a set in which each element is associated with a non-empty family of neighborhoods called the neighborhood system of the element. Let NS(x) denote the neighborhood system of x in a Fréchet (V) Space. A Fréchet (V) Space is called a reflexive (V) Space if for all x 2 U, K 2 NSðxÞ ) x 2 K; it is called a symmetric (V) Space if for all x, y 2 U, K 2 NSðxÞ ^y 2 K ) K 2 NSðyÞ:
From a covering C, we can obtain a neighborhood system. Definition 9. Suppose C is a covering of U. A neighborhood system CðC; xÞ of x is defined by:
div.formula: CðC; xÞ ¼ fKjK 2 C; x 2 Kg # C:ð18Þ
div.p: In the definition, C may be viewed as a mapping from C Â U to P(P(U)
div.formula: C ¼ [ fCðC; xÞjx 2 Ug:ð19Þ
div.p: That is, C is the union of all neighborhood systems of objects in U.
In general, from a covering C, we can construct a reflexive and symmetric (V) Space by:
div.formula: NSðxÞ ¼ CðC; xÞ ¼ fKjK 2 C; x 2 Kg:ð20Þ
div.p: Conversely, from a reflexive and symmetric (V) Space, we can construct a covering:
div.formula: C ¼ [ fNSðxÞjx 2 Ug:ð21Þ
div.p: The formulation provides a method to construct a one-to-one correspondence between the set of all coverings and the set of all reflexive and symmetric (V) Spaces. The construction process in fact proves the following theorem and its simple proof is omitted.

Theorem 4. There is a one-to-one correspondence between the set C of all coverings of U and the set V of all reflexive and symmetric (V) Spaces on U. In the neighborhood system CðC; xÞ, one can define a partial ordering on neighborhoods of x by using set inclusion. Based on this ordering, it is possible to select certain subsets of CðC; xÞ as new neighborhood systems of x. Bonikowski et al. [6] introduced the notion of the minimal description of the object x. Similarly, we can construct the maximal description of x.

Each subset K 2 mdðC; xÞ is a minimal neighborhood of x in the sense that no proper subset of K is in CðC; xÞ. The family mdðC; xÞ consists of all minimal neighborhoods of x in CðC; xÞ. Thus, we call it the minimal-description neighborhood system of x. Similarly, the family MDðC; xÞ consists of all maximal neighborhoods of x in CðC; xÞ, which is called the maximal-description neighborhood system of x.

The pair of neighborhood systems represents the extreme points of CðC; xÞ. For any neighborhood K 2 CðC; xÞ, we can find a pair of neighborhoods K 1 2 mdðC; xÞ and K 2 2 MDðC; xÞ such that K 1 # K # K 2 . The neighborhood system mdðC; xÞ has been used in many studies [39,54].

A plausible argument in favor of mdðC; xÞ may be stated as follows. In the classical rough set model, both U/E and r(U/E) are coverings of the universe. All subsets in r(U/E) can be constructed from U/E through set union. In fact, we have md(r(U/ E), x) = {[x] E jx 2 U}. In some sense, mdðC; xÞ may be similarly interpreted. However, in general there is no theoretical argument to justify this preference. It may be equally reasonable to use the system MD(C,x).

Zhu and Wang [87] introduced the notion of maximal description of a covering, which is the union of the maximal descriptions for all objects, namely, S fMDðC; xÞjx 2 Ug. The notion of maximal description of an object was recently considered by Mohanty [32].

div.head: Neighborhood operators induced by a covering
div.p: In order to apply the element based definition, we need to construct a special neighborhood system called 1-neighborhood system [61], in which each object has exactly one neighborhood. For any neighborhood system NS(x) of x, it may be difficult to design a criterion to select one neighborhood from NS(x). Instead, one can introduce the notion of the minimum and the maximum neighborhoods of x induced by NS(x). Definition 11. Suppose NS(x) is a neighborhood system of x. A pair of neighborhoods n 0 (NS(x)) and n 1 (NS(x)) induced by NS(x) is defined by:
div.formula: n 0 ðNSðxÞÞ ¼ \ fKjK 2 NSðxÞg; n 1 ðNSðxÞÞ ¼ [ fKjK 2 NSðxÞg:ð24Þ
div.p: By the definition, we have:
div.formula: 8K 2 NSðxÞ; n 0 ðNSðxÞÞ # K # n 1 ðNðxÞÞ:ð25Þ
It
div.p: The minimum neighborhood n 0 ðCðC; xÞÞ and the maximum neighborhood n 1 ðCðC; xÞÞ have been proposed and studied by many authors [31,38,39,47,57,79,87]. Pomykała [38,39] called n 1 ðCðC; xÞÞ the indiscernibility neighborhood of x, and Zhu [79,87] and Qin et al. [40] That is, the minimal neighborhood system only preserves the minimum neighborhood of CðC; xÞ, while the maximal neighborhood system only preserves the maximum neighborhood of CðC; xÞ. They show explicitly the missed information caused by using mdðC; xÞ and MDðC; xÞ. The equality properties were observed and given by some authors [9,31].

div.head: New coverings induced by a covering
div.p: For a covering C of U, we can construct four additional coverings by using the minimal and maximal neighborhood systems, and the minimum and maximum neighborhoods. Definition 13. From the covering C, four coverings C 1 ; C 2 ; C 3 and C 4 induced by C are defined as follows:
div.formula: C 1 ¼ [ fmdðC; xÞjx 2 Ug # C; C 2 ¼ [ fMDðC; xÞjx 2 Ug # C; C 3 ¼ fn 0 ðCðC; xÞÞjx 2 Ug; C 4 ¼ fn 1 ðCðC; xÞÞjx 2 Ug:ð29Þ
div.p: Some of these coverings are used either explicitly or implicitly by many authors [8,[38][39][40]. Both coverings C 1 and C 2 are subsets of C. The covering C 1 consists of all minimal neighborhoods of all x 2 U, and the covering C 2 consists of all maximal neighborhoods of all x 2 U. The coverings C 3 and C 4 are generated by the minimum neighborhoods and the maximum neighborhoods of all x 2 U, respectively. In general, C 3 and C 4 may not be subsets of C: One can also construct new coverings by using n 1 ðmdðC; xÞÞ and n 0 ðMDðC; xÞÞ.

For each of the new coverings, by following the previous discussions one may define its minimal-description and maximal-description neighborhood systems, and the minimum and maximum neighborhoods. The following theorem shows that some of these further derivations will not produce additional new structures. A proof of the theorem straightforwardly follows from the definitions of the notions involved and is thus omitted. The results have important implications for further research. For example, C 1 and C have the same minimal-description neighborhood systems and the same minimum neighborhoods for all x 2 U. Further applications of md and n 0 will not produce additional new coverings. On the other hand, we may have mdðC 2 ; xÞ -mdðC; xÞ, a further application of md may produce a new covering. This process may be carried on iteratively. For clarity, in this paper we restrict our discussion to only coverings C 1 ; C 2 ; C 3 and C 4 produced by the original C.

div.head: Reducts of a covering
div.p: In the classical rough set model, r(U/E) is generated by U/E through set union and some subsets in r(U/E) may be expressed as the unions of families of subsets in U/E. One can delete those subsets from r(U/E) to obtain U/E. A similar observation is also true for a covering. Following Pawlak's discussion on reducts of a family of sets [37], one can introduce the notion of reducts of a covering. The property of irreducibility of a covering with respect to set union was discussed by Mordeson [33]. The notion of a reduct of a covering was introduced by Zhu and Wang [82,83] and studied by other authors [8,22]. Definition 14. Let F be a family of non-empty subsets of U, namely, ; -F # P(U). If K is an intersection of some sets in F À {K}, then K is said to be an intersection reducible subset in F, otherwise K is said to be an intersection irreducible subset. If K 2 F is a union of some sets in F À {K}, then K is said to be a union reducible subset in F, otherwise K is said to be a union irreducible subset. If every subset in F is intersection irreducible, then F is said to be intersection irreducible; otherwise F is said to be intersection reducible. If every subset in F is union irreducible, then F is said to be union irreducible; otherwise F is said to be union reducible.
By definition, it can be verified that if K is an intersection reducible subset in F, then
div.formula: T F = T (F À {K}) and S F = S (F À {K}); if K is a union reducible subset in F, then S F = S (F À {K}) and T F = T (F À {K}).
div.p: The second condition is particularly interesting; the deletion of an intersection or a union reducible subset will not remove any element from S F. The following theorem states another important property of intersection (union) reducible elements of F. Theorem 6. Let F be a family of non-empty subsets of U. Suppose K 2 F is an intersection reducible subset in F, then for all K 1 2 (F À {K}), K 1 is an intersection reducible subset in (F À {K}) if and only if K 1 is an intersection reducible subset in F. Suppose K 0 2 F is a union reducible subset in F, then for all K 2 2 (F À {K 0 }), K 2 is a union reducible subset in (F À {K 0 }) if and only if K 2 is a union reducible subset in F.

A proof of the second part of the theorem concerning union reducible sets is given by a proposition in [83]. The first part concerning intersection reducible sets can be proved by using the same technique and is given in the Appendix. According to the theorem, we can simplify a family F by iteratively removing reducible subsets to obtain reduced forms of F, which are called reducts of F. Definition 15. Let F be a family of non-empty subsets of U. If F i is the set of all intersection reducible subsets in F, the set (F À F i ) is called the intersection reduct of F. If F u is the set of all union reducible subsets in F, the set (F À F u ) is called the union reduct of F.
The intersection reduct and the union reduct of F are unique and are denoted by \-reduct(F) and [-reduct(F), respectively. They can be computed by:
div.formula: \-reductðFÞ ¼ F À KjK 2 F; 9F 1 # ðF À fKgÞ½K ¼ \ F 1 n o ; [-reductðFÞ ¼ F À KjK 2 F; 9F 2 # ðF À fKgÞ½K ¼ [ F 2 n o :ð30Þ
div.p: The \-reduct and [-reduct are usually not the same. The notions of reducible subsets and reducts can be immediately applied to a covering and related structures. For a covering C of U, if K 2 C is an intersection (union) reducible subset in C, then C À fKg is still a covering of U. Therefore, both \-reductðCÞ and [-reductðCÞ are coverings of U. They are reduced representations of C. In the classical rough set model, we have
div.formula: \-reduct(r(U/E) À {;}) = {U} [ {U À [x] E jx 2 U} = {U} [ { $ [x] E jx 2 U} and [-reduct(r(U/E) À {;}) = U/E.
[-reductðC 1 Þ ¼ C 1 ; [-reductðC 3 Þ ¼ C 3 ; \-reductðC 2 Þ ¼ [-reductðC 2 Þ ¼ C 2 :
div.p: The proof of the theorem is given in the Appendix. Accordingly, coverings C 1 and C 3 are only [-irreducible, and covering C 2 is both \-irreducible and [-irreducible. In general, we may have:
div.formula: \-reductðC 1 Þ -C 1 ; \-reductðC 3 Þ -C 3 ; \-reductðC 4 Þ -C 4 ; [-reductðC 4 Þ -C 4 :
div.p: We can remove \-reducible subsets from C 1 ; C 3 , and C 4 to obtain their \-reducts, and remove [-reducible subsets from C 4 to obtain its [-reduct.

div.head: Subsystems induced by a covering
div.p: In the Pawlak rough set model, the r-algebra, r(U/E), is formed by making U/E to be closed under set union, which also happens to be closed under set complement and intersection. In order to generalize the subsystem based definition, we can construct a pair of dual systems S ¼ ðS; SÞ from a covering such that S is a closure system. There are two possibilities for defining such a system. Definition 16. Let C be a covering of a universe U. The intersection closure of C, denoted by \-closureðCÞ, is the minimum subset of P(U) that contains C; ; and U, and is closed under set intersection. The union closure, [-closureðCÞ, is the minimum subset of P(U) that contains C; ; and U, and is closed under set union.

By this definition, \-closureðCÞ is a closure system, and the dual of \-closureðCÞ, denoted by ð\-closureðCÞÞ 0 , is closed under set union. Similarly, the dual of [-closureðCÞ, denoted by ð[-closureðCÞÞ 0 is a closure system. They may be used to define approximation operators.
div.formula: \-closureðCÞ ¼ \-closureðC \ Þ; [-closureðCÞ ¼ [-closureðC [ Þ:
div.p: A simple proof of the theorem is given in the Appendix. An important implication of the theorem is that if the subsystem based definition is used, \-reductðCÞ and [-reductðCÞ will produce the same pairs of approximation operators. This observation provides a plausible justification for studying \-reduct and [-reduct of a covering.

div.head: Classification of covering based approximation operators
div.p: Within the framework proposed in Section 3, we can immediately investigate various classes of approximation operators by using the structures induced by a covering, as introduced in Section 4.

div.head: Approximation operators
div.p: With the element based, the granule based and the subsystem based definitions, one can obtain three families of approximation operators. Each family, in turn, consists of several pairs of approximation operators, depending on particular structures used. As shown in Table 1, there are a total of twenty pairs of approximation operators.

Other three pairs of approximation operators can be similarly defined. From a given covering C, we can construct six additional coverings, namely, C 1 ; C 2 ; C 3 ; C 4 ; C \ and C [ . By inserting each covering into the granule based definition, we obtain two pairs of approximation operators, namely, the tight pair and the loose pair. For example, by inserting C 1 , we obtain:
div.formula: apr 0 C 1 ðAÞ ¼ [ fKjK 2 C 1 ; K # Ag; apr 0 C 1 ðAÞ ¼ $ apr 0 C 1 ð$ AÞ; apr 00 C 1 ðAÞ ¼ $ apr 00 C 1 ð$ AÞ; apr 00 C 1 ðAÞ ¼ [ fKjK 2 C 1 ; K \ A -;g:ð35Þ
div.p: Other pairs of approximation operators can be similarly defined and are listed in Table 1.
With respect to the subsystem based definition, we can use the two subsystems:
S \ ¼ ðð\-closureðCÞÞ 0 ; \-closureðCÞÞ;
div.formula: S [ ¼ ð[-closureðCÞ; ð[-closureðCÞÞ 0 Þ:ð36Þ
div.p: This leads to two pairs approximation operators:
div.formula: apr S\ðAÞ
div.p: They are listed at the bottom of Table 1.

To conclude this subsection, we make several comments on the results in Table 1. First, if one uses the concept based definition, this list can be further expanded. The results of Table 1 may be viewed as examples of approximation operators based on a covering. Second, Table 1 contains operators proposed and studied by many authors and new operators. For a review of operators that have been proposed in existing studies, see Table 2 in the next subsection. At the same time, it should be pointed out that some existing approximation operators are not covered by this table. In order to produce these operators, one needs to search for additional definitions (e.g., concept based definition) and new structures. Nevertheless, the general framework, as shown by Fig. 1, is still applicable. Third, some operators in Table 1 are closely related. For example, the tight pair and loose pair defined by a covering are related. The pairs of operators apr 00 C ; apr 00 C and ðapr N 4 ; apr N 4 Þ are, in fact, the same, namely, apr 00 C ¼ apr N 4 and apr 00 C ¼ apr N 4 . It will be interesting to investigate systematically relationships among the twenty pairs of operators. Fourth, each pair of approximation operators reflects the information provided by a specific aspect of a covering. From a pure theoretical point of view, one may only study their mathematical properties; it is difficult to argue which pair is more reasonable, meaningful or useful. In order to answer this question, one must fall back to the semantics of a covering in particular applications.

div.head: Summary of studies on covering based approximation operators
div.p: Based on the approximation operators from Table 1, we are ready to summarize the main results from the existing studies.

Table 2 is a summary of the most commonly used covering based approximation operators published before the end of 2009. We group them into three groups, the first group consists of pairs of dual approximation operators, the second group consists of pairs of non-dual approximation operators, and the last group consists of pairs of operators such that only one operator is from Table 1 and the other is not. For example, the pair ðapr 0 C ; ÁÞ indicate that only the lower approximation operator apr 0 C is used and the upper approximation operator is defined differently from any of the upper approximation operators in Table 1. The column labeled by ''references'' provides only some examples that use the particular pair of operators; they are not intent to be an exhaustive list. To illustrate the historical development, references are ordered according to the year of publication. Table 2 may be read together with the brief review of Section 2.

One can make some useful observations from Table 2. First, the proposed framework enables us to reproduce many existing approximation operators and to introduce new approximation operators. It shows that the proposed framework is reasonable and may help us to obtain a better understanding of approximation operators. Differences between different operators stem from the fact that they are obtained by generalizing different formulations of the Pawlak approximation operators. Each of them captures a different aspect of approximation with a covering. It is theoretically difficult to justify which is more reasonable. Some authors reject _ Zakowski upper approximation by the fact that it is a very loose upper bound. Without considering the structure of a covering, such a criticism has to be carefully examined. As shown in the table, we can obtain several additional coverings. The _ Zakowski upper approximation may, in fact, be meaningful for some of these coverings.

Second, some of the existing approximation operators are not present in Table 2. In order to contain such definitions, one may use the same conceptual framework by considering other definitions of Pawlak approximation operators. Alternatively, one may consider other structures induced by a covering. In this case, the same framework can be used. In some sense, the results in Table 2 may be considered as examples of applying the general concept framework given in the Introduction by Fig. 1.

Third, Fig. 1 and Table 2 offer possible future research topics. For example, one may study relationships between these approximation operators. One may investigate an axiomatic system for each of these operators. One may examine the conditions under which some operators will become the same. One may establish a linkage between properties of a covering and properties of approximation operators.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: A general framework is proposed and examined for the study of covering based rough sets. We first review equivalent formulations and definitions of Pawlak approximation operators and then generalize them to the context of a covering. We consider three formulations and three definitions, namely, the equivalence relation based formulation with element based definition, the partition based formulation with granule based definition, and r-algebra based formulation with subsystem based definition. This framework enables us to reproduce many existing approximation operators and to introduce new approximation operators.

From a covering of universe, we construct four different neighborhoods, six new coverings, and two subsystems. Together, they give rise to twenty pairs of dual approximation operators. These operators reflect a wide range of different aspects of approximations under a covering. Based on the proposed framework, one can also study additional approximation operators. In addition, the same framework may be used to investigate approximation operators with other mathematical structures.

div.head: Appendix A. Proofs of theorems
div.p: Theorem 6 (the first part). Let K be an intersection reducible subset in F. In this paper, we only consider a finite set U and, consequently, a finite family F. This means that K can be expressed as the union of a finite family of subsets, say {G 1 , . . . , G m }, from (F À {K}), that is, K = G 1 \ . . . \ G m and K -G i , 1 6 i 6 m. Suppose that K 1 is an intersection reducible subset in (F À {K}), by definition it is also an intersection reducible subset in F. Now assume that K 1 -K is an intersection reducible subset in F, that is, K 1 = M 1 \ . . . \ M n , where M j 2 F À {K 1 }. For the expression of K 1 , we need to consider two cases. Case 1: K -M j for any 1 6 j 6 n. It follows that M j 2 ((F À {K}) À {K 1 }). Thus, by definition K 1 is an intersection reducible subset in (F À {K}). Case 2: K is one of M j 's. Without loss of generality, we assume K = M 1 . We have

It can be verified that G i -K 1 for any 1 6 j 6 m, for otherwise we would have K = K 1 . Therefore, G i 2 ((F À {K}) À {K 1 }) and M j 2 ((F À {K}) À {K 1 }) for 1 6 i 6 m and 2 6 j 6 n. One can also conclude that K 1 is an intersection reducible subset in (F À {K}).
Theorem 7. We only prove the first equality and the same technique can be used to prove the others. To prove

there must exist an object x 2 U such that K 2 mdðC; xÞ. This implies that x 2 K. By the expression of K, there must exist a subset K i 0 , 1 6 i 0 6 r, such that x 2 K i 0 . From K i 0 2 C 1 # C and K i & K, one can conclude that K i 0 is a neighborhood of x that is strictly smaller than K. This results in a contradiction to K 2 mdðC; xÞ. Thus, K must be [-irreducible.

Theorem 8. By the definition of \-reduct, we can easily generate a subset in C by taking the intersection of a family of subsets in C \ . That is, we can obtain C from C \ through an application of set intersection. By the definition of \-closure, it easily follows that C and C \ will produce the same \-closure. Similarly, by the definitions of [-reduct and [-closure, we can show that C and C [ will produce the same [-closure.
